title: Load balancing
i
Â enables our service to scale well and stay highly available when the traffic load increases. Load balancing is facilitated byÂ
load balancers
i
, making them a key component in the web application architecture.

Load balancers distribute heavy traffic load across the servers running in the cluster based on several different algorithms. This averts the risk of all the traffic converging to a single or a few machines in the cluster.

If the entire traffic on a particular service converges only to a few machines, this will cause an overload, subsequently spiking the latency, also bringing down the applicationâ€™s performance. The excess traffic might also result in the server nodes going offline. Load balancing helps us avoid all this mess.

While processing a user request, if a server goes down, the load balancer automatically routes the future requests to other up and running server nodes in the cluster. This enables the service as a whole to stay available.
Load balancers act as a single point of contact for all the client requests.

They can also be set up at the application component level to efficiently manage traffic directed towards any application component, be it the backend application server, database component, message queue, or any other. This is done to uniformly spread the request load across the machines in the cluster powering that particular application component.
Performing health checks of the servers with load balancers
b
b
To intelligently route all the user requests to the active nodes in the cluster, a load balancer should be well aware of their running status.
To ensure that the user request is always routed to the machine that is up and running, load balancers regularly perform health checks on the machines in the cluster.

Ideally, a load balancer maintains a list of machines that are up and running in the cluster in real-time, and the user requests are forwarded to only those machines in service. If a machine goes down, it is removed from the list.
Machines that are up and running in the cluster are known asÂ
in-service
i
Â machines, and the servers that are down are known asÂ
out-of-service
i
Â instances.
For the record,Â Node, Server, Server Node, Instance, andÂ MachineÂ all mean the same thing and can be used interchangeably.
After theÂ
out-of-service
i
Â instance comes back online and becomesÂ
in-service
i
, the load balancer updates its list and starts routing the future requests to that particular instance all over again.
Every machine that is online and is a part of theÂ
World Wide Web
i
Â (WWW) has a uniqueÂ
IP address
i
Â that enables it to be contacted by other machines on the web using that particularÂ
IP address
i
IP
i
Â stands forÂ
Internet Protocol
i
. Itâ€™s a protocol that facilitates the delivery of data packets from one machine to another using their IP addresses.
2001:db8:0:1234:0:567:8:1
i
Â - This is an example of a machineâ€™sÂ
IP address
i
. The server that hosts our website will have a similarÂ
IP address
i
. To fetch content from that server, a user has to type in the unique IP address of the server in their browserâ€™s URL tab and hit enter to interact with the websiteâ€™s content.
Naturally, it is not viable to type in the websiteâ€™s IP address from memory every time we visit a particular website. Even if we try to, how many IP addresses do you think you can remember?
Typing in domain names, for instance,Â
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
, is a lot easier than working directly with IP addresses. I think we can all agree on this.
Domain name system
i
, commonly known asÂ
DNS
i
, is a system that averts the need to remember longÂ
IP addresses
i
Â to visit a website by mapping easy-to-remember domain names to IP addresses.
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â is a domain name that is mapped to its uniqueÂ
IP address
i
Â by theÂ
DNS
i
Â so that we are not expected to type in theÂ
IP address
i
Â ofÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â into our browsers every time we visit that website.
How does a domain name system work?
b
When a user types in theÂ
URL
i
Â of the website in their browser and hits enter, this event is known asÂ
DNS querying
i
Four key components, or a group of servers, make up the DNS infrastructure. These are:
DNS Recursive nameserver aka DNS Resolver
i
When the user hits enter after typing in the domain name into their browser, the browser sends a request to theÂ
DNS Recursive nameserver
i
b
, also known as theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
The role ofÂ
DNS Resolver
i
Â is to receive the client request and forward it to theÂ
Root nameserver
i
Â to get the address of theÂ
Top-Level domain nameserver
i
b
b
TheÂ
DNS Recursive nameserver
i
Â is generally managed by ourÂ
ISP
i
Â (Internet service provider). The wholeÂ
DNS
i
Â system is a distributed system setup in large data centers managed by internet service providers.
These data centers contain clusters of servers optimized to processÂ
DNS
i
Â queries in minimal time in milliseconds.
Once theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
Â forwards the request to theÂ
Root nameserver
i
b
, theÂ
Root nameserver
i
Â returns the address of theÂ
Top-Level domain nameserver
i
Â in response. As an example, the top-level domain forÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â isÂ
.com
i
Once theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
Â receives the address of theÂ
top-level domain nameserver
i
, it sends a request to it to fetch the details of the domain name. Top Level domain nameservers hold the data for domains using their top-level domains.
For instance, theÂ
.com
i
Â top-level domain nameserver will contain information on domains usingÂ
.com
i
. Similarly, aÂ
.edu
i
Â top-level domain nameserver will hold information on domains usingÂ
.edu
i
Since our domain isÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
, theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
Â will route the request to theÂ
.com
i
b
Â top-level domain name server
b
Once the top-level domain name server receives the request from theÂ
Resolver
i
, it returns theÂ
IP address
i
Â of theÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â domain name server.
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â domain nameserver is the last server in theÂ
DNS query lookup
i
Â process. This nameserver is responsible for theÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â domain and is also known as theÂ
Authoritative nameserver
i
b
. The owner of the domain name owns this nameserver.
Then,Â
DNS Resolver
i
Â fires a query to theÂ
Authoritative nameserver
i
, and it returns theÂ
IP address
i
Â of theÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â website to theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
DNS Resolver
i
Â caches the data and forwards it to the client.
On receiving the response, the browser sends a request to theÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â websiteâ€™sÂ
IP address
i
Â to fetch data from their servers.
Often all thisÂ
DNS
i
Â information is cached, and theÂ
DNS
i
Â servers donâ€™t have to do so much rerouting every time a client requests anÂ
IP
i
Â of a certain website.
TheÂ
DNS
i
Â information of websites that we visit also gets cached in our local machines, that is, our browsing devices with aÂ
TTL
i
Â (Time to live).
All modern browsers do this automatically to cut down theÂ
DNS
i
Â query lookup time when revisiting a website.
In the previous lesson, we discussed how theÂ
DNS query lookup
i
Â process works and the role of different servers in the domain name system. The end server, in the lookup chain, is theÂ
authoritative server
i
, which returns theÂ
IP address
i
Â of the domain.
When a large-scale service such asÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â runs, it needs way more than a single machine to run its services. A service as big asÂ
amazon.com
i
a
http://amazon.com/
Â is deployed across multiple data centers in different geographical locations across the globe.
To spread the user traffic across different clusters in different data centers. There are various ways to set upÂ
load balancing
i
. In this lesson, we will discussÂ
DNS load balancing
i
, which is set up at theÂ
DNS
i
Â level on theÂ
authoritative server
i
DNS load balancing
i
Â enables theÂ
authoritative server
i
Â to return differentÂ
IP addresses
i
Â of a particular domain to the clients. Every time it receives a query for anÂ
IP
i
, it returns a list ofÂ
IP addresses
i
Â of a domain to the client.
With every request, theÂ
authoritative server
i
Â changes the order of theÂ
IP addresses
i
Â in the list in aÂ
round-robin
i
Â fashion.
As the client receives the list, it sends out a request to the firstÂ
IP address
i
Â on the list to fetch the data from the website. The reason for returning a list ofÂ
IP addresses
i
Â to the client is to enable it to use otherÂ
IP addresses
i
Â in the list in case the first doesnâ€™t return a response within a stipulated time.
When another client sends out a request for anÂ
IP address
i
Â to theÂ
authoritative server
i
, it re-orders the list and puts anotherÂ
IP address
i
Â at the top of the list following theÂ
round-robin
i
Â algorithm.
Also, when the client hits anÂ
IP
i
, it may not necessarily hit anÂ
application server
i
. Instead, it may hit anotherÂ
load balancer
i
Â implemented at the data center level that manages the clusters of application servers.
DNS load balancing
i
Â is largely used by companies to distribute traffic across multiple data centers that the application runs in. However, this approach has several limitations.
For instance, it does not take into account the current load on the servers, the content they hold, their request processing time, their in-service status, and so on.
Also, since theseÂ
IP addresses
i
Â are cached by the clientâ€™s machine and theÂ
DNS Resolver
i
, there is always a possibility of a request being routed to a machine that is out of service.
DNS load balancing
i
, despite its limitations, is preferred by companies because it is an easy and less expensive way of setting upÂ
load balancing
i
Â on their services.
There are primarily three modes of load balancing:
We discussedÂ
DNS load balancing
i
Â in the previous lesson. In this one, we will look intoÂ
hardware
i
Â andÂ
software load balancing
i
Hardware-based
i
Â andÂ
software-based load balancing
i
Â are common ways of balancing traffic loads on large-scale services. Letâ€™s begin withÂ
hardware-based load balancing
i
Hardware load balancers
i
Â are highly performant physical hardware. They sit in front of theÂ
application servers
i
Â and distribute the load based on the number of currently open connections to a server, compute utilization, and several other parameters.

Since these load balancers are physical hardware, they need maintenance and regular updates, just like any other server hardware would need. They are also expensive to set up compared to software load balancers, and their upkeep may require a certain skill set.
Also, the hardware load balancers have to be overprovisioned upfront to deal with peak traffic, which is not the case with software load balancers.
But when it comes to performance, hardware load balancers stand out.

If the business has network specialists and an IT team in-house, they can manage these load balancers. Otherwise, the developers are expected to wrap their heads around setting up these hardware load balancers with some assistance from the vendors. This is also the primary reason why developers prefer working withÂ
software load balancers
i
Now, letâ€™s take a look atÂ
software-based load balancing
i
Software load balancers
i
Â can be installed onÂ
commodity hardware
i
Â andÂ
VMs
i
. They are more cost-effective and offer more flexibility to the developers.Â
Software load balancers
i
Â can be upgraded and provisioned easily compared to hardware load balancers.
You will also find several
Â
b
Load Balancers as a Service
i
b
Â (LBaaS)
b
services online that enable you to directly plug in load balancers into your application without you having to do any sort of setup.
Software load balancers
i
Â are pretty advanced compared toÂ
DNS load balancing
i
. They consider many parameters such asÂ
data hosted by the servers, cookies, HTTP headers, CPU and memory utilization, load on the network
i
, etc., to route traffic across the servers.
They also continually perform health checks on the servers to keep an updated list of in-service machines.
Development teams prefer to work with software load balancers as hardware load balancers require specialists to manage them.
HAProxy
i
a
https://www.haproxy.com/
Â is one example of a software load balancer widely used by the big guns in the industry, includingÂ
GitHub, Reddit, Instagram, AWS, Tumblr, StackOverflow
i
, to scale their systems.
Besides the round Robin algorithm, whichÂ
DNS Load balancers
i
Â use, software load balancers leverage several other algorithms to efficiently route traffic across the machines. Letâ€™s take a look.
Algorithms/Traffic routing approaches leveraged by load balancers
b
Round robin and weighted round robin
b
We know that theÂ
round robin algorithm
i
Â sendsÂ
IP addresses
i
Â of machines sequentially to the clients. Parameters such as the server load, CPU consumption, and so on are not considered when sending the IP addresses to the clients.
We have another approach known as theÂ
weighted round robin
i
, where based on the serverâ€™s compute and traffic handling capacity, weights are assigned to them. And then, based on server weights, traffic is routed to them using theÂ
round robin algorithm
i
With this approach, more traffic is converged to machines that can handle a higher traffic load, thus efficiently using the resources.

This approach is pretty useful when the service is deployed across multiple data centers having different compute capacities. More traffic can be directed to the larger data centers containing more machines.
When using this algorithm, the traffic is routed to the machine with the least open connections of all the machines in the cluster. There are two approaches to implement this.
I
n the first, it is assumed that all the requests will consume an equal amount of server resources, and the traffic is routed to the machine with the least open connections based on this assumption.
b
In this scenario, there is a possibility that the machine with the least open connections might already be processing requests demanding most of itsÂ
CPU
i
Â power. Routing more traffic to this machine would not be a good idea.
In the other approach, theÂ
CPU
i
b
Â utilization and the request processing time of the chosen machine are also considered
b

before routing the traffic to it. Machines with the shortest request processing time, most negligible CPU utilization, and the least open connections are suitable candidates to process future client requests.
The least connections approach comes in handy when the server has long opened connections like persistent connections in a gaming application.

Following this approach, the traffic is randomly routed to the servers. The load balancer may also find similar servers in terms of existing load, request processing time, and so on. Then it randomly routes the traffic to these machines.
In this approach,
the source IP where the request is coming from and the request URL are hashed
b
to route the traffic to the backend servers.
Hashing the source IP ensures that a clientâ€™s request with a certain IP will always be routed to the same server.
This facilitates a
better user experience
b

as the server has already processed the initial client requests and holds the clientâ€™s data in its local memory. There is no need for it to fetch the client session data from the session memory of the cluster and process the request. This reduces latency.
Hashing the client IP also enables the client to re-establish the connection with the same server that was processing its request in case the connection drops.
Hashing a URL ensures that the request with that URL always hits a certain cache that already has data on it. This is to ensure that there is no cache miss.
This also averts the need for duplicating data in every cache and is, thus, a more efficient way to implement caching.
